Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2008 05:50AM EGAL wrote: Pip,  I was dx on 10/19/06.  I had a large hard mass that my GYN dismissed 1 1/2 years before.  My GP finally sent me for ultrasound.  After core biopsy it was determined to be cancer.  It was >7 cm tumor plus 2 more that never showed on mammograms which MRI showed.  I has mast. and had 17 out of 20 lymph nodes found to have cancer.  Had 4 AC, 4 Taxotere, 6 weeks radiation and now 36 Herceptin treatments which I am half through.  I had reconstruction and a prophylatic mast. on left with reconstruction this September.  I am just dealing and hoping for the best.  I am working full- time and have some issues with pain/ache with the implants but I am doing okay.  You'll do just as well :)

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 08:31AM EGAL wrote: I totally agree with MRI's being necessary for some people.  I found a lump, went to my GYN who tried to aspirated it, he told me it wasn't cancer, had a mammogram a few months later which was fine.  So they said.  Six months later lump still there, asked my GP to check it and he sent me for U/S.  After a biopsy it was cancer (the tumor as 12 cms. = 4 1/2 inches, and mammo couldn't pick that huge thing up) and my BS sent me for an MRI before he would operate.  The MRI showed 3 tumors that were never detected on mammo.  After surgery, path showed 15 lymph nodes had cancer.  Stage 3, grade 3!   I am NOT a fan of mammograms. Update~ Dx'd with brain mets 10/01/08.  GET AN MRI !!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2010 05:24PM EGAL wrote: I loved having the port.  I had it for more than a year, as I had chemo and one year of Herceptin.  It can get itchy and I still don't wear my seat belt over the scar.  I had it out about 1 1/2 years ago.  It saved my veins as I could only use one arm.  The say it is simple to but in but I was put out and the next few days my neck hurt.  No one told me that would happen.  I had port on Friday and used it the next Tuesday for chemo.  It was fine, just a little sensitive. Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2009 11:27AM EGAL wrote: I had Adriamycin and Cytoxin at the same time (4 infusions every three weeks).  I didn't have too much trouble with it but did get a UTI after the first treatment.  Please be sure your mom drinks lots of anything to flush out the Red Devil.  I thought I had plenty to drink but I still got the UTI, which was worse than the SE from treatment.   Also, mom should tell Onco if anti-nausea meds don't seem to be working, there are lots and if one doesn't work another will.  I had to change after second treatment.  I am also HER+, and after the AC, I had 4 infusions of Taxotere.  That really effected my tastebuds.  It was awful, and nothing tasted good except watermelon, ice cream and chicken noodle soup.  Didn't happen with AC though.  Good luck to your mom and let us know if we can answer anything.   Ellen

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 05:11PM EGAL wrote: Hi Dasiyhope,  I wish I lived near you, I'd come right on over and give you a hug I am going on my second year of this stuff so I can tell you it is doable (even though I was scared to death of my first chemo and wanted to bolt from the evelvator.)  I had 8 rounds of chemo which I drove to alone all but the first one (as I figured I was going to be puking my guts out, didn't happen).  I drove to all six weeks for radiation which was about 30 - 40 mintes each way and drove to my 36 weekly Herceptin treatments.  You'll do fine, but if you feel you need at ride contact your local ACS and they may help you will transportation.    I'll keep you in my thoughts and prayers!

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2008 01:55AM EGAL wrote: Hi Carol,   I was dx'd when I was 51. I am married with a 24 year old daughter who was living on her own in Boston when I went through chemo.  I am glad to be alone when I don't feel well so there was not much interaction with anyone when was going through chemo.  I just had my reconstruction on the non-cancer side three weeks ago.  Had the port out too.  So it's been a long journey.  I was out of work for one year.  I am back but I am very tired still.  Dr's. have NO idea why!!!!  I just carry on and hope for the best.   I had a Persian just like that and the photo tells how I feel about this cancer stuff.  We now have a 18 lb., long haired gray & white guy.  He as an attitude but when I don't feel well he knows and becomes my lap buddy.  Funny how pets know what to do If you ever what someone to talk to, send me a private message and I'll email you my home phone.

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2009 09:54PM EGAL wrote: Please get it checked!  My GYN blew me off, said that the lump he tried to aspirate was not cancer. Well, after a year and a half, I asked  my GP to check it and he sent me for a ultrasound.  It was cancer and now I am stage 4.  Don't let anyone dismiss your concerns.  I wish I hadn't. I was 51 but had a lumpectomy on the same breast when I was 18.  That wasn't cancer but my mom had BC, so I was very diligent on getting my mammos.  It never showed on that, I have (had) dense breasts and the tumor was very high on my chest more than in the breast. Ellen

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 09:30PM EGAL wrote: I got GOOD NEWS!  Had dx of brain mets on Sept. 30th, and had GAMMA  KNIFE Surgery on 10/05.  I am still having some off-balanceness and weird headaches.  It will be another 3 or so weeks before MRI of brain to see if the large tumor is shrinking. But ONCO ordered  scans of bones, abdomen, chest wall, and pelvis.  I had those this Wednesday and last night my PCP called me at home to tell me  that ALL scans were clear. I wasn't expecting a call that fast and I was pertified when he  said he was calling to see if I was doing okay.  He then went into the report.  I thought (of course) he was calling with bad news as the ONCO did, with the brain mets.  Hubby was working and I called DD who lives out of town.  She called right back and at least I got out "I have good news" before I broke down sobbing so badly that she couldn't  understand a word.  I finally composed myself and shared the rest.  I was SO prepared for bad news, I could hardly handle the good.

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2007 02:06AM EGAL wrote: I thought I was the only one with taste bud issues!  No one I talked with had much problems but mine were the worst.  I had 4 A/C and only had a icky taste in my mouth and I could suck on hard candy or chew gum to relieve that. But the very day I had Taxotere it was the pits!  EVERYTHING tasted awful...not metallic but "flat" as some folks mentioned.  I couldn't eat bread, rolls, sweets (chocolate or cookies).  For weeks I ate carrots, watermelon and ice cream.  I actually cried one day due to frustration of being hungry for food and not being able to eat.  That lasted for the whole time of Taxotere (I had 4 tx every 3 weeks.)  I finished Taxotere on May 15th and things are much better but I still sometimes ask hubby and daughter "does this taste strange or is it just me".  It's just me   I would say that was the worst part of chemo for me even more than losing my hair.    However, my hair is really slow to grow and what is coming in is curly, frizzy and straight on different areas...weird!!!!

Posts.Title: Off to surgery again.... LuAnnH heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 09:03PM EGAL wrote: I was getting more and more tired as the weeks passed.  I kept tell Onco that I was so very tired and getting depressed from it.  He blamed chemo, rads, recent surgery, Herception, blah, blah, blah!!! I went to GP for regular check up and told him I couldn't take much more of feeling "shitty" and he ordered blood tests.  Found out that I had hypothyroidism.  I am now taking Synthroid I managed to go back to work,  put almost 5 months later I am still not feeling right.  I had my dosage lower 3 months ago after I was on Synthroid for 8 weeks.  It was too strong and I had heart palpatations, nervousness, shaking, etc. I just had a blood test yesterday, so GP will call with results soon.   Mayo Clinic website and a few others say that radiation can cause hypothyroidism.  You'd think oncologists (medical and radiation) would know this and order routine tests for it.  Just google Synthriod or hypothyroidism and you'll see the symptoms.  I had many of them but they also can be attributed to chemo, rads, herception (weight gain, depression, feeling cold, puffy face, etc. I had them all!)  This is all too much to deal with EGAL Fast forward 6 months...still feel like crap.  Synthroid was 44 mcg, then 88, then 75, now 50. GP says it's on target now, hummm?  I have 3 more Herceptin infusions left and I am hoping that is making me tired.  After working all week, I can't even get showered and dressed on Saturday.  I HATE all this!  Plus my BP is now sky high and I have to take meds for that.  Does it ever end? Dx 10/19/2006, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IIIc, Grade 3, 17/15 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ [Edit] [Delete]

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 07:13PM - edited Sep 8, 2009 07:14PM by EGAL KLee,   I had 4 rounds of Taxotere, once every three weeks.  I didn't need Neulasta shots was my WBC stayed good.  But I didn't fare was well as I did on AC (4 rounds of those).  Like LRM16 said it was the taste buds that really made it miserable.  EVERYTHING tasted awful, bread, crackers, water.  I ended up eating watermelon, ice cream and chicken noodle soup.  Still I DIDN'T lose weight.  I think that Taxotere added weight.  I did have bone pain and aches, I was kinda miserable but the worst was that I was hungry but whatever I put in my mouth revolted me.  I would nearly come to tears when a Burger King commercial came on, as I wanted to eat something, anything, but I knew even if I tried it would be awful.  It started the morning after my first treatment and took a few months after last to get back to full tasting.  I hope it is not as bad as that for you, you can't afford to loose weight.  Good luck and keep us posted! Ellen

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2008 04:47PM - edited Apr 23, 2008 08:58PM by EGAL I was getting more and more tired as the weeks passed.  I kept tell Onco that I was so very tired and getting depressed from it.  He blamed chemo, rads, recent surgery, Herception, blah, blah, blah!!! I went to GP for regular check up and told him I couldn't take much more of feeling "shitty" and he ordered blood tests.  Found out that I had hypothyroidism.  I am now taking Synthroid I managed to go back to work,  put almost 5 months later I am still not feeling right.  I had my dosage lower 3 months ago after I was on Synthroid for 8 weeks.  It was too strong and I had heart palpatations, nervousness, shaking, etc. I just had a blood test yesterday, so GP will call with results soon.   Mayo Clinic website and a few others say that radiation can cause hypothyroidism.  You'd think oncologists (medical and radiation) would know this and order routine tests for it.  Just google Synthriod or hypothyroidism and you'll see the symptoms.  I had many of them but they also can be attributed to chemo, rads, herception (weight gain, depression, feeling cold, puffy face, etc. I had them all!)  This is all too much to deal with Fast forward 6 months...still feeling like crap.  Synthroid was 44 mcg, then 88, then 75 now 50.  GP says it is now on target..hummm?  I still feel like crap, I only have 3 more Herceptin infusions left and I am hoping that I will not be so tired after that.  Also, now my BP is sky high and I am on blood pressure pills.  Is there no end to this?  Still up 25 pounds and can't get rid of it.  WTF!?!
Posts.Title: Radiation Damaged My Thyroid Katiejane paige-allyson

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 03:15PM EGAL wrote: Hey Lisa,   I was dx'd with brain mets on Sept. 30th and on October 5th, I had GAMMA KNIFE Surgery.  It is a large tumor (can't remember the size) but Neurosugeron said it was a 6 out of 10 ??!???  I had been off balance and had weird headaches (I would wake up at night with a "tight band around my back skull and all around like a halo) but thought is was my blood pressure.  It had been happening for about 2 weeks or so and I had a regular appt. with Onco so mentioned it to him  He thought it was tension, but sent me a few days later for a MRI and there it was!!!!  I am hoping the GAMMA will take care of it....other options will be surgery and WBR neither of which I really think I can deal with.  On a good note...on Wednesday I had bone scan, abdomen, pelvis and chest CT's and they were all clear.  Even my PCP and Onco were surprised it went to brain first.  Are you a candiate for GAMMA? We can beat this ~
Posts.Title: Me, too LisaSDCA EGAL

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 12:20PM EGAL wrote: Lisa,  My onco is scheduling brain MRI for the end of  December.  I wanted it now but he said it was too soon.  He said 3 months (I thought neuosurgeon said two).  He said he wanted to see more improvement than less.  He said there would still be tumor, swelling and scarring from the GAMMA.  I don't think anyone told me about the scarring.  Wonder what that will do long term???!!  So I wait...hope.

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2009 01:51AM EGAL wrote: I think you can expect some swelling for a while.  I wouldn't worry unless it is red and hot or you have a fever.  You should be able to call the dr, even if it is the weekend.  The answering service should be able to give you the dr. covering, if your's is off.  Or if you think you need to, go to the ER.  I have learned over this long journey to listen to your gut instinct and if you don't feel right, be your own advocate.  Let us know how you are doing! Ellen

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2008 09:20AM EGAL wrote: Lisa,  Tomorrow will be six weeks since GAMMA. At time of dx, Onco put me on Dexametasone 4mg x3 daily.  It was necessary to reduce the swelling from the tumor.  Tumor was very close to area the drains cerebral fluid down the spinal column.  If swelling got worse, I could have had a seizure.  It the cerebral fluid couldn't drain, I would have had to emergency surgery.  Thankfully, that didn't happen but the steroid is very hard to deal with.  I am gradually reducing the dosage and it is better but I couldn't sleep more than a few hours at a time and the mood swings were incredible.  I see Onco this week and I think he'll order the follow-up MRI to check on the tumor.  I still have the pain and headaches, but in my mind it is the tumor shrinking
Posts.Title: Me, too LisaSDCA EGAL

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2008 02:43PM EGAL wrote: I have good news, too! I began to get off-balance again last week and after a few days I called onc.  He saw me immediately and thought that it could be caused from the gradual decrease of decadron. (I have been on it since Sept. 30th when dx of brain mets.  Gamma knife on Oct. 6th, and MRI was to be on Dec. 30th but he got me a test right away.)  MRI shows that the large tumor has shrunk by nearly 1/2 and there are no new lesions.  So I can deal with the side effects of weaning off the decadron knowing it the tumor is not the cause or there is a new one.  He did increase the steroids for a short time.  I hate what it does.  I've gained 30 lbs since chemo and this,  I look like the Michelen Man!
Posts.Title: Me, too LisaSDCA EGAL

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2008 11:00AM EGAL wrote: Lisa,   Yes, I do have swelling...seems all over. Even my lips feel puffy.     A woman I have know for over 30 years, didn't recognize me in the store the other day until I spoke to some else and she heard my voice.  GRRRR.....  I usually am good about dealing with everything that has happened, but this really shook me to the core.  As the symptoms were the same as just before dx, I was sure it was the tumor or new ones.  I am so relieved! Your report will be as good in six weeks!!!!!!!

Posts.Title: good scans jan125 katie11

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 08:28PM EGAL wrote: I wish I could be happy again. I am so uncomfortable with this implant and expander (had prophylatic mastectomy, that exchange will be in August).  The permanent is so uncomfortable and PS doesn't know why!!!  I think it is from the rads, as whole chest wall is still tender to the touch. I am grouchy all the time because I don't sleep well and have to work with only a few hours each night of sleep.  I am sad (probably depressed, too) that this cancer has struck all of us.  I want a vaccine for my daughter and a cure of us.  I want to know why I was "blown off" by my GYN and was dx'd 18 months later with Stage 3.  Should I have trusted him? NO!  Should I have questioned the mammo that said all was clear only 6 months before dx? YES! (I knew there was a thickening as I pointed out to GYN).  WHY DID ALL THIS GET SO BAD??  My mother was dx'd early and she was fine with a lumpectomy and rads.  I had mastectomy, 8 rounds of chemo, 30 rads, reconstruction, 36 Herceptin infusions, and I still wonder what will happen next.  It SUCKS!

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2009 07:48PM EGAL wrote: I had single tumor about 2cm., had Gamma Knife last October.  It was shrinking and I am having an MRI on 10/20/09 and hoping it is gone and there are no others.  The worst part of the treatment (the halo that was screwed into my skull was no picnic, though) was the Decadron (steroid) that I was on for 4 months.  Never slept, was wound up like a top, always hungry, and gained a lot of weight.  I also looked like a blowfish.  Even my lips were puffy.  I didn't even recognize myself and neither did others.  Still carrying lots of weight in my middle.  Not sure if it is that or the ice cream Ellen

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 03:48PM EGAL wrote: I have brain mets and my symptoms were off-balanceness and dull headache, especially in the a.m.  It got better as the day progressed.  I thought it was my blood pressure and was going to get that checked but had an appt. with onco and mentioned the headache.  He said it could be stress but he ordered a CT and it showed one large tumor.  Had a MRI and no others were detected.  I had GAMMA Knife radiation and it is shrinking.  I still have headaches in that area and in other spots too.  Ask Dr. for an MRI.  It will but your mind at ease.

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2009 12:56AM EGAL wrote: I only have a choice of the chalky, berry flavored stuff.  I have to drink two bottles, beginning two hours (total of 4 cups) before scans.  I use a straw and make sure it is very, very cold.  I do okay with the first two cups, the third is so-so and the final one, I am gagging.  Hate that stuff!  Ellen
Posts.Title: CT Scan stuff neogirl konakat

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2010 12:13PM EGAL wrote: I've had brain mets for one year.  Had Gamma Knife radiation in January last year.  I had one tumor and was on steriods immediatley as not to have a seizure.  I had Gamma Knife, just a few days after dx.  I am doing okay, the tumor has shrunk but not totally gone. I am not having any problems so no treatment is need.  My onco said that there is no chemo that will get the the brain.  I am not sure of Tykerb, but have heard of gals that have it. The steriods are pretty bad, as you are really wired and can't sleep but for a few hours a night.  Good time to get some heavy duty cleaning done LOL.  But it stopped my headaches almost immediately.  I was on them for 4 months and got the moon face but I goes away. Good luck and keep us posted! Ellen
Posts.Title: need reassurance brain mets her2+ pr/er-_ pbandj tami444

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2009 08:13PM EGAL wrote: The encouraging news is that there are more trials that will be beginning and that they are hoping for new drugs that will be able to be more targeted.  Also, the life expectancy for brain mets patients was 3 months years ago and continues to increase.  I think the average was 50 months but I believe we will all be cured, either by surgery, GAMMA, radiosurgery or WBR!  We're gonna whipped those little buggers~  As bmdaley says the was lots of medical jargon and I didn't grasp too much of it.  I was disappointed in the brain mets workshop but glad the bone mets was good for you guys.
